summary: The NFDI4Ing archetype Golo focuses on improving data acquisition in field experiments, which are characterized by uncontrollable environmental conditions. key_takeaways.title: Challenges in Field Experiments
key_takeaways.detail: Field experiments are conducted in environments where conditions cannot be fully controlled, such as testing driver assistance systems in traffic or monitoring urban traffic. key_takeaways.title: Importance of Comprehensive Documentation
key_takeaways.detail: Accurate documentation of field conditions (e.g., weather, soil composition, time of day) and experiment details (e.g., personnel roles) is crucial for interpreting recorded data and ensuring its reuse. This documentation helps in understanding how external factors may have impacted the experiment.

key_takeaways.title: Survey Insights on Current Practices
key_takeaways.detail: A survey conducted among engineers revealed that current solutions for field experiments are often domain-specific and individualized, with few commonly known standards. key_takeaways.title: Workflow Integration for Field Experiments

title: NFDI4Ing Community Survey: Results & Call to Participate!
summary: The NFDI4Ing consortium conducts annual surveys to assess the state of research data management (RDM) in engineering sciences. The fourth survey is currently open until December 31, inviting engineers to share their experiences and needs regarding RDM. Previous surveys have provided insights into data types, volumes, and researchers' familiarity with RDM concepts and tools.

key_takeaways.title: Diverse Data Types in Engineering Research
key_takeaways.detail: Engineering researchers primarily generate data in the form of texts (86%), tables (76%), models (69%), and source code (64%). This diversity underscores the need for versatile RDM strategies to accommodate various data formats.

key_takeaways.title: Moderate Data Volumes Per Researcher
key_takeaways.detail: Most engineering researchers report handling low to medium amounts of data annually per employee. This suggests that while data management is crucial, the volume per individual may not be overwhelming, allowing for more focused RDM practices.

key_takeaways.title: Limited Familiarity with Key RDM Concepts
key_takeaways.detail: Surveys from 2022 and 2023 reveal that concepts like metadata standards (33%), data management plans (22%), and the FAIR principles (23%) are among the least familiar to respondents. This indicates a need for increased education and resources in these areas.

key_takeaways.title: Growing Awareness of NFDI4Ing
key_takeaways.detail: Awareness of the NFDI4Ing consortium has been increasing, with 59% of respondents in 2022 and 66% in 2023 indicating familiarity. This trend suggests effective outreach efforts but also highlights the need for continued promotion.

key_takeaways.title: Preference for Interactive RDM Services
key_takeaways.detail: Among those familiar with NFDI4Ing, interactive services such as Community Meetings and Special Interest Groups are particularly valued. This preference points to the importance of collaborative and engaging platforms in supporting RDM practices.

It enables detailed tracking of traffic flows and classification of various road users, providing an alternative to costly on-site personnel or automated methods that may lack accuracy. Additionally, it can generate ground truth data to benchmark the accuracy of automated traffic counting systems.

key_takeaways.title: Manual Traffic Counting Using Video Footage
key_takeaways.detail: OTGroundTruther allows users to perform manual traffic counts by analyzing video recordings of intersections or road cross-sections. This approach facilitates detailed tracking of traffic flows and the ability to distinguish between different classes of road users, such as pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists, cars, buses, and trucks. By leveraging existing video material, the tool provides a cost-effective alternative to deploying personnel on-site for traffic counting tasks.

key_takeaways.title: Generation of Ground Truth Data for Benchmarking
key_takeaways.detail: Beyond manual counting, OTGroundTruther can generate ground truth data sets. These data sets serve as a benchmark to evaluate and improve the accuracy of automated traffic counting systems, such as OpenTrafficCam. By providing a reliable reference, the tool aids in the development and validation of automated methods, ensuring they meet required accuracy standards before deployment.

key_takeaways.title: Open-Source and Customizable
key_takeaways.detail: Licensed under the GPL-3.0 license, OTGroundTruther is open-source software, allowing users to freely use, modify, and distribute the tool. This openness promotes transparency and enables customization to meet specific requirements or adapt to different traffic counting scenarios. Users can tailor the tool to their needs, enhancing its applicability across various contexts.

key_takeaways.title: User-Friendly Interface with Comprehensive Features
key_takeaways.detail: Designed with ease of use in mind, OTGroundTruther features an intuitive interface that includes functionalities such as displaying counted traffic objects directly on the video frame to prevent double counting, providing an overview of all counted objects for quick navigation and editing, and offering help instructions accessible via a help button. These features streamline the traffic counting process and reduce the likelihood of errors.

key_takeaways.title: Integration with Other Tools for Enhanced Functionality
key_takeaways.detail: OTGroundTruther integrates with other tools like OTAnalytics, which is used to create the necessary gate files (otflow or otevents) required for counting. This integration enhances the tool's functionality, allowing for a more comprehensive analysis of traffic data. By combining multiple tools, users can achieve a more detailed and accurate understanding of traffic patterns and behaviors.

title: NFDI-RFC Standardisation Concept
summary: The NFDI-RFC Standardisation Concept outlines a framework for developing and disseminating technical specifications to enhance research data management infrastructure. It proposes establishing a platform, inspired by the IETF's Request For Comments (RFC) model, to rapidly communicate new guidelines and standards within the scientific community. This initiative aims to facilitate the creation of discipline-specific solutions, such as data formats and metadata standards, and to promote their adoption across various research fields. The ultimate goal is to evolve these guidelines into established standards (e.g., DIN/ISO) that have been tested in practice and widely supported by the research community.

key_takeaways.detail: The concept advocates for creating a platform modeled after the Internet Engineering Taskforce's (IETF) Request For Comments (RFC) system. This platform is intended to expedite the dissemination of new guidelines and standards in research data management (RDM) to the scientific community, ensuring that advancements are communicated efficiently and effectively.

key_takeaways.title: Development of Discipline-Specific Solutions

key_takeaways.title: Promotion of Quasi-Standards Leading to Established Standards
key_takeaways.detail: The initiative envisions that the guidelines and solutions disseminated through the RFC platform will serve as quasi-standards. Over time, these can evolve into established standards, such as those recognized by DIN or ISO, after being tested in practice and gaining broad support from the research community. This progression aims to ensure the long-term viability and acceptance of the standards.

key_takeaways.title: Enhanced Discoverability and Usability

title: SciMesh
summary: SciMesh is a specification developed by NFDI4Ing to represent scientific insights as knowledge graphs, focusing on sample-based workflows. It aims to facilitate seamless data exchange between electronic lab notebooks (ELNs) and enhance the sharing, reuse, and archiving of research results.

key_takeaways.title: Knowledge Graph Representation
key_takeaways.detail: SciMesh represents scientific insights as knowledge graphs, emphasizing sample-based workflows where samples undergo sequences of processing and measurement steps. This approach captures the cause-effect relationships inherent in empirical science.

key_takeaways.title: Facilitating ELN Interoperability
key_takeaways.detail: By standardizing data representation, SciMesh enables seamless data exchange between different electronic lab notebooks (ELNs), allowing researchers to collaborate effectively even when using different ELN software.

key_takeaways.title: Ontology Stack for Flexibility
key_takeaways.detail: SciMesh employs a layered ontology stack, combining a core vocabulary with subsets of existing vocabularies for basic scientific and bibliographic concepts. This structure balances interoperability with the flexibility to incorporate specialized, community-defined vocabularies.

key_takeaways.title: Reference Implementations
key_takeaways.detail: NFDI4Ing has developed reference implementations of SciMesh in ELN software packages such as JuliaBase, eLabFTW, and Kadi4Mat, demonstrating its practical applicability and facilitating adoption in the scientific community.

key_takeaways.title: Enhancing Data Sharing and Reuse

title: SM4RO-C – SciMesh for RO-Crate
summary: SM4RO-C (SciMesh for RO-Crate) is a specification designed to enhance the interoperability and reproducibility of scientific data by embedding SciMesh graphs into RO-Crate containers. This integration results in self-contained artifacts that encompass scientific results, their context, provenance, and associated bulk data, facilitating seamless data sharing and publication.

key_takeaways.title: Integration of SciMesh and RO-Crate
key_takeaways.detail: SM4RO-C combines SciMesh, a framework for representing scientific workflows as knowledge graphs, with RO-Crate, a method for packaging research data with rich metadata. This integration creates comprehensive, machine-actionable containers that encapsulate both raw data and detailed metadata, including the complete workflow leading to the scientific results.

key_takeaways.title: Enhanced Data Sharing and Reproducibility
key_takeaways.detail: By embedding SciMesh graphs into RO-Crate containers, SM4RO-C enables researchers to share well-defined research data objects, such as all data related to a semiconductor device, with peers. This approach not only facilitates data sharing but also ensures that the data's provenance and context are preserved, enhancing reproducibility.

key_takeaways.title: Support for Electronic Lab Notebooks (ELNs)
key_takeaways.detail: SM4RO-C containers can be utilized by electronic lab notebooks to exchange data between different instances or to export data for backup or migration purposes. This functionality promotes interoperability among various ELN systems and ensures that research data remains accessible and well-documented.

key_takeaways.title: Specification and Reference Implementation
key_takeaways.detail: SM4RO-C is a specification that can be implemented by various platforms. NFDI4Ing is developing a reference implementation within JuliaBase, providing a concrete example of how the specification can be applied to create self-contained research data artifacts.

key_takeaways.title: Contribution to FAIR Principles
key_takeaways.detail: By creating containers that include both raw data and rich metadata in a structured, machine-readable format, SM4RO-C contributes to the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) principles. title: A-Match: Facilitating Data Exchange Between Different Applications via API Matching
summary: The A-Match project addresses the challenge of data exchange between heterogeneous software tools in engineering by developing a system that matches attributes of different APIs, enabling seamless data flow in toolchains. The project resulted in an open-source tool that combines user input with automated matching suggestions to facilitate interoperability.

key_takeaways.title: Challenge of Heterogeneous Software Landscapes
key_takeaways.detail: Engineering research often involves a variety of software tools with differing data formats and conventions, making seamless data exchange difficult. This heterogeneity complicates the creation of automated toolchains, necessitating manual data conversions that are time-consuming and error-prone.

key_takeaways.title: Development of A-Match Tool
key_takeaways.detail: To address these interoperability issues, the A-Match project developed a system capable of matching attributes between different APIs. This tool allows users to select APIs and data objects, manually match terms, or utilize automated matching suggestions generated by the system's backend, which employs distance metrics and ontologies to identify synonyms.

key_takeaways.title: User-Centric Design and Feedback
key_takeaways.detail: The development process of A-Match was highly user-focused, involving two workshops with the NFDI4Ing community to gather feedback and refine the tool's functionality and usability. This collaborative approach ensured that the tool met the specific needs and preferences of its intended users.

key_takeaways.title: Open Source Availability
key_takeaways.detail: Upon completion, the A-Match tool was released as open-source software, making it accessible to the broader engineering community. This openness encourages further development, adaptation, and integration into various research workflows, promoting widespread adoption and improvement.

key_takeaways.title: Enhancing Research Efficiency
key_takeaways.detail: By facilitating accurate and efficient data exchange between diverse software applications, A-Match enhances the efficiency of research processes. It reduces the manual effort required for data conversion, minimizes errors, and supports the creation of automated toolchains, thereby accelerating the pace of engineering research and innovation.

title: Final Report: Development of a Portfolio of Tools for the Creation and Documentation of Reproducible Simulation Workflows
summary: This report presents the outcomes of a project aimed at developing a suite of tools to facilitate the creation and documentation of reproducible simulation workflows in computational science and engineering. By evaluating existing workflow management systems (WfMSs) against specific requirements derived from user stories, the project provides guidance for researchers in selecting appropriate tools to enhance transparency, adaptability, and reproducibility in their computational research.

key_takeaways.title: Importance of Reproducible Simulation Workflows
key_takeaways.detail: The report underscores the necessity for reproducible simulation workflows in computational science and engineering to ensure transparency, adaptability, and trustworthiness in research findings. By automating workflows and providing comprehensive documentation, researchers can facilitate external verification and reuse of their work.

key_takeaways.title: Evaluation of Workflow Management Systems (WfMSs)
key_takeaways.detail: The project assessed various WfMSs to determine their suitability for describing, reproducing, and reusing scientific workflows. This evaluation was based on general requirements derived from user stories pertinent to computational science and engineering, aiding researchers in selecting tools that best fit their needs.

key_takeaways.title: Development of a GitHub Repository for Workflow Implementations
key_takeaways.detail: A GitHub repository was created to host implementations of exemplary workflows using different WfMSs. This resource serves as a practical guide for researchers, demonstrating how various tools can be employed to create reproducible workflows and encouraging their adoption in daily research activities.

key_takeaways.title: Formation of a Special Interest Group (SIG)
key_takeaways.detail: The project led to the establishment of a Special Interest Group within NFDI4Ing focused on workflow tools. This group facilitates ongoing collaboration, feedback, and knowledge sharing among researchers interested in reproducible simulation workflows, promoting continuous improvement and community engagement.

key_takeaways.title: Collaboration with NFDI4Ing Task Areas
key_takeaways.detail: The project engaged in close cooperation with multiple NFDI4Ing task areas and members, particularly in the context of reproducible workflows in high-performance computing (HPC) environments and the use of container technology. These collaborations led to synergies with other research projects, enhancing the project's impact and relevance.

title: Final Report: FAIR Workflows - Connecting Engineering Research Outputs using PID Infrastructure
summary: This report details the outcomes of a project aimed at enhancing the implementation of FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) principles in engineering research through the use of Persistent Identifiers (PIDs) and standardized metadata. The project successfully developed best practice guidelines, mapped metadata schemas to improve interoperability, and created interactive dashboards to visualize research outputs and their interconnections.

key_takeaways.title: Development of Best Practice Guidelines for DOI Registration
key_takeaways.detail: The project produced comprehensive guidelines to assist researchers and data curators in registering Digital Object Identifiers (DOIs) for various research outputs. These guidelines emphasize the importance of standardized metadata to enhance the discoverability and reusability of engineering research data.

key_takeaways.title: Mapping DataCite Metadata Schema to Schema.org
key_takeaways.detail: To improve interoperability across different platforms, the project mapped the DataCite Metadata Schema to Schema.org. This alignment facilitates better integration and exchange of metadata, making engineering research outputs more accessible and interconnected.

key_takeaways.title: Creation of Interactive Dashboards for Data Visualization
key_takeaways.detail: Interactive dashboards were developed to visualize the consortium's research outputs, their interconnections, and data reuse patterns. These tools aid in monitoring key performance indicators related to the FAIRness of engineering data management practices.

key_takeaways.title: Collaboration with DataCite and TIB DOI Konsortium
key_takeaways.detail: The project collaborated with DataCite and the TIB DOI Konsortium to provide PID services tailored to the specific needs of the engineering community. This partnership aimed to address the challenges of standardizing research output metadata and promoting the adoption of PIDs in engineering research.

key_takeaways.title: Enhancing FAIR Principles Implementation in Engineering Research
key_takeaways.detail: By integrating PIDs and standardized metadata, the project significantly advanced the implementation of FAIR principles in engineering research. This approach ensures that research outputs are more findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable, thereby increasing their impact and facilitating collaboration.

title: Final Report: Development of a Graphical Interface for Corrections and Additions by Users When Expanding Ontologies  OntoHuman
summary: The OntoHuman project aimed to enhance ontology development by integrating a graphical user interface that allows users to correct and add information, thereby improving the automatic extraction of data from technical documents. This approach facilitates the enrichment of ontologies, making them more accessible and usable across various engineering domains.

key_takeaways.title: Human-in-the-Loop Approach
key_takeaways.detail: OntoHuman employs a Human-in-the-Loop (HiL) strategy, enabling users to provide feedback on automatically extracted information, which is then used to refine and expand ontologies. This collaborative process bridges the gap between automated systems and domain experts, ensuring more accurate and comprehensive ontological representations.

key_takeaways.title: Domain-Agnostic Application
key_takeaways.detail: Initially tailored for space engineering documents, OntoHuman has been adapted to support various engineering domains. Users can upload customized ontologies, allowing the system to extract and annotate data from documents across different fields, thereby broadening its applicability.

key_takeaways.title: Graphical User Interface Enhancements
key_takeaways.detail: The project focused on developing an intuitive web-based user interface that allows users to correct extracted data, resolve ambiguities, add new annotations, and export annotated information. These enhancements improve user experience and facilitate more effective ontology enrichment.

key_takeaways.title: Integration with Existing Tools
key_takeaways.detail: OntoHuman builds upon prior tools like the Data Sheets Annotation Tool (DSAT), integrating the HiL component to generalize the automatic information extraction process. This integration allows for the application and customization of ontologies used for extracting data from documents of other domains.

key_takeaways.title: Open Source Availability
key_takeaways.detail: The source code for OntoHuman has been published on Zenodo, making it accessible for further development and adaptation by the research community. This openness encourages collaboration and continuous improvement of the tool.

title: Final Report: Metadata Framework and Rich Provenance Tracking System for Conductive Inks in Printed Electronics - ReCIPE
summary: The ReCIPE project aimed to develop a comprehensive metadata framework and provenance tracking system for conductive inks in printed electronics. By implementing the Kadi4Mat platform, the project established a structured approach to document process parameters and outcomes, facilitating process optimization and knowledge sharing within the research community.

key_takeaways.title: Identification of Kadi4Mat as the Preferred Platform
key_takeaways.detail: After evaluating various platforms, including eLabFTW and Chemotion, the project team selected Kadi4Mat due to its balance of existing structures and flexibility for modeling processes. Its in-house development at KIT and a growing user base further supported this choice.

key_takeaways.title: Establishment of Data and Metadata Structures for Conductive Inks
key_takeaways.detail: The project developed and implemented a data and metadata structure specifically for conductive metallic inks (Au, Ag, Pt). This structure enables systematic documentation of process parameters and outcomes, addressing the challenge of optimizing combinations of materials, methods, and processing parameters.

key_takeaways.title: Integration of Experimental Data into the Framework
key_takeaways.detail: The team began populating the Kadi4Mat system with experimental data, creating a rich provenance tracking system. This integration allows for comprehensive tracking of samples and data across different process chains, enhancing reproducibility and process optimization.

key_takeaways.title: Addressing the Need for Standardized Information Exchange
key_takeaways.detail: ReCIPE tackled the challenge of exchanging information on methods, process chains, sample treatments, and device performances in a standardized and openly accessible manner. This effort aims to facilitate knowledge sharing and collaboration within the printed electronics community.

key_takeaways.title: Ongoing Efforts to Expand the System
key_takeaways.detail: The project continues to add experimental data and processes to the system, reaching out to academic and industry colleagues. This expansion aims to develop an exhaustive provenance tracking system for samples and data collected across various process chains.
